awd_titl_txt: WAIS Workshops 2019-2021: An Annual Transdisciplinary Forum for Studies of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet by the next Generation of Polar Scientists
awd_abstract_narration:
The West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) Workshop has been held annually for the past quarter century. It offers a key venue for transdisciplinary scientific exchange on the state and behavior of WAIS, processes that influence its changing behavior, and projections of its future mass balance and sea-level contribution. The community-based structure of the workshops brings together students, early-career, and senior scientists who are investigating WAIS using a wide variety of tools. Researchers present on finding obtained from ground-based and shipborne methods, airborne geophysics, satellite remote-sensing, and numerical modeling. Group interactions facilitate collaborations and help researchers answer difficult, but essential, questions regarding the fate of WAIS. This award provides partial support for the next three years of WAIS Workshops, to be held in Julian, California (2019), Sterling, Virginia (2020), and the Denver, Colorado region (2021).

This set of three workshops will (1) promote the dissemination of innovative WAIS science with dedicated open discussion periods, (2) welcome new scientific ideas from disciplines that were underrepresented in past workshops, (3) establish new initiatives to grow a more inclusive community and accessible meeting that connects with community college educators, and (4) implement a formal mentoring plan for graduate students, post-doctoral, and other early-career researchers. These efforts will maximize the efficacy of the WAIS Workshop as a forum that pushes the boundaries of scientific understanding of WAIS. They will also ensure that the research community is positioned to engage and support the next generation of polar scientists.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: TRUSTEES OF THE COLORADO SCHOOL OF MINES

por.por_cntn:
This award provided approximately one third of the required support for the 2019, 2020, 2021, 2022, and 2023 West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) Workshops. The WAIS Workshop brings together students, early-career, and senior scientists who are investigating WAIS using ground-based and shipborne methods, airborne geophysics, satellite remote-sensing, and numerical modeling all under the same roof to answer difficult, but essential questions regarding the fate of WAIS. The workshops funded by this award took place in Julian, CA (2019), virtually (due to the COVID pandemic in 2020), Sterling, VA (2021), Estes Park, CO (2022), and Cloquet, MN (2023), all in "retreat-style" settings in order to promote scientific discussion and collaboration. We successfully grew the conference to accommodate 100-120 in-person participants (except in 2020 when we had 166 virtual participants), provided a synchronous livestreaming option starting with the 2020 Workshop, and archived videos of the scientific programs on YouTube. The WAIS Workshop video archive now includes nearly 76 hours of the latest transdisciplinary West Antarctic science (including 241 individual science presentations) freely available online for streaming. We also implemented a new blind-review system to guide our allocation of oral and poster presentations from submitted abstracts that resulted in a change in the demographics of our oral presenters. Finally, we held a suite of extended community discussions and half-day workshops as part of the formal WAIS Workshop agendas that covered topics including harassment while performing field research in Antarctica, early career impacts of the COVID19 pandemic, the experience of members of historically underrepresented communities in West Antarctica, mental health and well-being in academics and fieldwork, equitable collaboration, community college education and curriculum development, working with data repositories, and collaborative cloud computing.
